title: To Copy or Not to Copy
narrative:
In this specification we cover the behaviour of tensors with respect to their copy methods. There are to main ways to copy a tensor:
1. .shallowCopy()
2. .deepCopy()

The first method creates a new tensor with the same underlying data array as the original tensor.
The second method on the other hand creates a new tensor with a new data array.

The first method is the most efficient, but it is not as safe as the second method.
The second method is the most safe, but it is not as efficient.

Besides these 2 main requirements, there are als some corner cases with respect to the components of a tensor (like for example its computation graph) which will be covered in this specification as well.

features.id: A deep copy of a tensor is also a deep copy of the underlying data array.

blocks.text: A tensor of ints with shape (2, 3).
The underlying data array is as expected.
We create a deep copy of the tensor.
The copy is not the same instance as the original tensor.
The shape and underlying data array are equal to the original tensor but the data is not identical.

features.id: A deep copy of a slice tensor is also a deep copy of the underlying data array.

blocks.text: A slice of ints with shape (2, 2) sliced in-place from a tensor of shape (3, 3).
The underlying items and data array is as expected.
We create a deep copy of the tensor.
The copy is not the same instance as the original tensor.
The underlying items and data array are as expected.
The slice and the copy have the same shape.
We verify that they share the same ints through the "every" method.

features.id: A shallow copy will share the same underlying data as its original tensor.

blocks.text: A tensor of ints with shape (2, 3).
The underlying data array is as expected.
We create a shallow copy of the tensor.
The copy is not the same instance as the original tensor.
We verify that they share the same ints through the "every" method.
